text: since the novel has come out I have
become but um previously I was never I
never felt part of the Iranian diaspora
Community I never knew where they were
um in Los Angeles um I had very little
contact with the Youth of Tangela
um partially because I never I didn't
relate to them my family wasn't wealthy
we weren't a bunch of you know doctors
lawyers engineers and and we were not
encouraged to be the be doctors lawyers
Engineers either um we were sort of an a
slightly artsy nerdy um family with um
my father's an academic and we grew up
very modestly in in um a small suburb
and I had very little contact with them
and when I would see them those those
types of Iranians I I felt a slight
sense of revulsion um
because they they were the first you
know I felt that in trying to um become
Americans they had sort of done it to
such an exaggerated degree you know he
suddenly had you know Beverly Hills High
kids you know were platinum blonde tons
of designer clothes you know BMWs
Mercedes it was like everything about
American culture that I I didn't like
done to Absolute excess um and so I I I
really never met them and then when I
went to Sarah Lawrence College in New
York there were few half Iranian kids
and that was about it and they were sort
of like me they they hadn't really grown
up in an um Iranian American immigrant
community so I never had the chance to
be around them much um then when the
novel came out um it it did get the
support of an Iranian American community
and I was able to see that there were
other Iranians um like myself who didn't
fit into that tulus culture that I was
grew up very phobic of um and that was
wonderful and and now I'm in touch with
lots of um Iranian and Iranian American
um artists writers musicians um and they
come to some of my readings
um um and and it's mostly wonderful I
get emails from a lot of people in Iran
actually uh who can't get the book but
who've heard about it you know Iran
Iranians and Iran are on the on the
internet all the time they're obsessed
with blogs and all that um so they've
discovered me a little bit and I get
sort of interesting emails from them um
which is fun I I've gone a lot of them
trying to figure out what my name means
what am I mother Muslim or not I I get
this all the time even in readings um
you know there'll always be some older
Iranian guy who will come up to me and
ask me my religion which I I find very
startling
um uh but the Iranians in Iran are
hilarious I had one guy uh an old um he
seemed like an older carpet seller and
he wanted to he was he gave me a long
speech in his email about what an honor
was for an Iranian to be getting press
and congratulations on your Victory it
said and then he uh said you know would
you be interested in buying these uh
incredible rugs he does of zor asrian um
image imagery um in in very broken
English so he he was trying to do
business I guess but um it was lovely
but I I I I correspond a lot with some
of the um English-speaking um bloggers
in Iran who are incredibly Progressive
and Incredibly bright and interesting
and are very curious about what's going
on here um and I get a some some emails
I'm on Goodreads and I run in uh
literature of the Iran and the diaspora
uh group there and I constantly get
emails from the Iranians there who they
they're always asking well what are you
guys reading what are the good novels by
middle easterners in the US because all
you people ever do is recommend the kit
Runner to us and we hate the kit
Runner they can't believe they they I I
can't tell you how many emails I've
gotten from Iranians who just seem so
upset about the Kite Runner being a hit
here they think the writing is
pedestrian which I think is very funny
